title: Lost in America
descriptions:
Albert Brooks’s 1985 satire Lost in America follows David and Linda Howard, a successful but restless yuppie couple in Los Angeles who decide to upend their comfortable lives after David is passed over for a promotion. Embracing a fantasy inspired by Easy Rider, they liquidate their assets, buy a winnebago, and set off to “drop out” of the materialistic rat race and find authentic freedom across the American landscape.

Their plan quickly collides with reality. Their nest egg—symbolically dubbed their “nest-egg”—is disastrously wiped out in a single night when Linda, prone to impulsiveness, loses almost everything at a Las Vegas roulette table. With their grand experiment derailed, the couple ping-pongs through a series of humbling encounters and dead-end jobs, from small-town living to menial work, revealing how ill-equipped they are for the unvarnished America they romanticized.

As their money and patience dwindle, David’s self-righteous monologues—aimed at casino managers, fast-food bosses, and anyone who’ll listen—expose the couple’s entitlement and denial. Meanwhile, their relationship strains under the weight of lost security and clashing expectations. The film turns their odyssey into a comedic autopsy of 1980s consumer culture, dissecting the myth that freedom can be bought by simply opting out.

Ultimately, the Howards abandon their countercultural experiment and retreat toward the stability they once scorned, driving back to the corporate world with chastened realism. Lost in America blends sharp observational humor with cringe-inducing situational comedy, using the couple’s misadventures to lampoon yuppie idealism and the gulf between aspirational fantasies of reinvention and the stubborn, often unforgiving realities of American life.
